data.title: Mollison, Jean (1861-1951)

data.text:
Jean Mollison was the manageress of Glencoe Lodge in Vancouver.

The original location of Glencoe Lodge was at 1001 Georgia Street from 1907 to 1931. (Further information appears on this page: Glencoe Lodge.)

A smaller and shorter-lived version of Glencoe Lodge was at 2020 Barclay Street from late 1931 to 1934.

Birth Date

Jean Mollison was born in Scotland in the 1860s. Many records from later years suggest that she was born about 1869.

However, the National Records of Scotland system has an entry for “Jane Mollison,” who was born in Wick, Caithness on May 21, 1861. Her parents were James Mollison and Anne Bisset. The birth register said that the date of James’s and Anne’s marriage was October 22, 1853, which was only one day away from the date of October 21, 1853 in the record of their marriage.

The 1871 and 1881 Scottish census records also support a birth year in the early 1860s for Jean. There are two entries for the Mollison family in the 1871 Scotland census. One listed Jean as “Wm Mollison” [female], who was born at Wick, Caithness, about 1862; the other said that she was “Jean Mollison,” who was born at Caithness about 1862.

The 1881 Scotland census described her as “Jeannie Mollison,” born at Wick, Caithness about 1862.

Family Background

Jean’s father, James Mollison, was born in Scotland in 1826. (The 1901 Canada census gave his birth date as November 14, 1823.)

It appears that James was born in Kincardine, Aberdeen, and that his parents were George Mollison (1782-1856) and Margaret Jolly (1782-1857).

George Mollison was a farmer at Mill of Campfield, Kincardine O’Neil. He died in September 1856, and he was buried in Banchory-Ternan Kirkyard in Banchory, Aberdeenshire.

After George died, his heirs sold the crops, animals, and equipment that were associated with the farm.

Margaret Mollison died on December 26, 1857. She was buried in Banchory-Ternan Kirkyard in Banchory.

James Mollison: Early Life

In 1841, James Mollison was living with his parents at Mill of Campfield, Kincardine O’Neil.

In 1851, he was a farm manager at Kinchyle, southwest of Inverness.

On October 21, 1853, in Dores, southwest of Inverness, James married Anne Bisset, who was born in Inverness about 1827 (or 1830).

Starting about 1863 and continuing almost uninterrupted until the early 1880s, the Mollisons lived at Dochgarroch Lodge, Inverness, where James was a factor (property manager) and land agent for the Baillie family.

James Scott Skinner, a well-known Scottish fiddler, wrote a song dedicated to Dochgarroch Lodge. (Paul Anderson plays a solo violin version of the song: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gk3XwVdVQOw.)

This extract from a Scottish ordnance survey name book cites “J. Mollison” as a source for the spelling of two place names near Dochgarroch: Battlefield and Balliemore.

Anne Mollison died in Inverness on February 26, 1876.

James Mollison and Anne Bisset had three boys and four girls.

Anne Elizabeth Mollison (1854-1929)

James William Mollison (1857-1927)

Hellen Mary Mollison (1859-1944)

Jean Mollison (1861-1951)

Jessie Mollison (1863-1929)

Andrew Oliver Mollison (1865-1891)

Robert Bisset Mollison (1869-1893)

In the early 1880s, James was still living at Dochgarroch Lodge, along with four children: Annie, Jeannie, Andrew and Robert. James was employed as Dochgarroch Lodge’s factor in 1883.

In September 1884, the Baillies ended James Mollison’s job as factor. On September 29, 1884, the Mollisons moved to Pavenham, which is north of Bedford in England. According to one record, they lived at East End Farm, which is about two kilometres east of Pavenham.

James claimed that his dismissal from Dochgarroch Lodge was illegal, and he sued the Baillies for £2500 in damages. The Baillies offered to pay one year’s salary instead.

In January 1885, the court denied James’s claim for £2500, and it agreed that one year’s salary was proper compensation. James also had to pay the legal expenses for the Baillies.

(The full report of the case appears here: Mollison v. Baillie (1885) Scottish Law Reporter, volume 22, pages 595-597 (January 10, 1885); https://www.bailii.org/scot/cases/ScotCS/1885/22SLR0595.html; https://www.bailii.org/scot/cases/ScotCS/1885/22SLR0595.pdf.)

It appears that James became financially insolvent during the middle and late 1880s. James Mollison of Pavenham, Bedfordshire, England (“lately residing at Dochgarroch”) petitioned himself into bankruptcy on March 31, 1888. The final dividend to his creditors was payable on October 3, 1889.

His trustee in bankruptcy was released in 1891.

To Canada

James Mollison and his children moved to Canada in the late 1880s. According to the available information, they did not come all at once.

Jean Mollison recollected that the oldest daughter, Annie, arrived in Canada in May 1888. Annie became a housekeeper at the Canadian Pacific Railway’s hotel at Banff, in the Rocky Mountains.

James Mollison, Jean’s father, was in Canada by the fall of 1888, when he wrote a letter to the editor of the Calgary Herald.

Jean recalled that she herself had arrived in July 1888, and she became the assistant housekeeper at the hotel in Banff.

“Miss Helen M. Mollison,” who appears to be Jean’s sister, arrived in Canada on July 23, 1889.

In late 1889 the older Mollison sisters became the managers of the Canadian Pacific Railway hotel in the Fraser Canyon.

The Lister-Kaye Company

In February 1889, James Mollison was the manager of the Canadian Agricultural Coal and Colonization Company, which was often called the “Lister Kaye estate.”

Sir John Pepys Lister-Kaye (sometimes spelled “Lester Kaye”) was a baronet who led a British syndicate that obtained large areas of land from Canadian Pacific Railway, in what is now Saskatchewan and Alberta. The original plan was to mix farming and ranching.

In the spring of 1889, James wrote a series of articles about the resources and development of western Canada. At that time, he was still a manager for the Canadian Agricultural Coal and Colonization Company.

A combination of challenging weather conditions and lack of experience soon resulted in operational and financial failures for the Lister-Kaye company.

Sir John Lister-Kaye later had other financial difficulties as well, and he became bankrupt in 1914.

Sir John Lister-Kaye died in 1924.

James Mollison: to Willow Creek

By the fall of 1889, James Mollison was no longer with the Lister-Kaye enterprise.

He bought a farm at Willow Creek, which is north of Fort MacLeod (sometimes simply called “MacLeod”).

According to an 1899 letter from the Calgary and Edmonton Land Company, the location of the farm was the “South Half and the Northeast Quarter of Section 23, Township 9, Range 26, West of the Fourth Meridian.” (This converts to: 49°44’45.4″N 113°24’41.8″W or Latitude 49.7459473; Longitude: -113.4115961: Alberta Energy Regulator conversion tool: https://www1.aer.ca/GISConversionTools/ats_degrees_converter.html.)

In October 1889, the Calgary Herald described the Mollison family’s move to Willow Creek.

At the time of the 1891 Canada census, James was living on the farm at Willow Creek, along with his sons, Andrew and Robert. (Both sons died in the 1890s.)

In 1899, James offered his property for sale, although it appears that the sale did not take place.

James was still living at Fort MacLeod in 1902, when he went to Glacier, British Columbia, to visit his daughter. (A newspaper article describing his trip called him “W.H. Mollison.”) He took a Scotch collie dog with him.

The Scotch collie may be the same dog that appears in this photograph of Jean Mollison at Lake Louise.

In the early 1900s, James continued to travel back and forth from British Columbia to the MacLeod area.

He also lived for periods of time with his daughters, Annie and Jean, at Calgary, and perhaps during the summer at Lake Louise.

By 1904, James was retiring from ranching, and he sold 80 head of cattle by auction.

James died at Calgary on October 12, 1905.

He was buried in the cemetery at Fort MacLeod, where two of his sons were also buried.

Jean Mollison: Early Years in the Mountain Hotels

The details of Jean Mollison’s early time in Canada are not always clear. Most sources rely on interviews with Jean in the 1930s and 1940s, although her memory of earlier details was sometimes imprecise.

From the late 1880s to the early 1900s, Jean and her sister, Annie, spent periods of time at several Canadian Pacific Railway hotels, including Banff, Field, Lake Louise, Glacier House, and North Bend. Sometimes they were both at one hotel at the same time; at other times they were on their own. (Mount Mollison in Kootenay and Yoho National Parks is named for Annie. A small railway point west of North Bend is named after Jean.)

Except for Banff and Lake Louise, at first the main function of the early railway hotels was to provide meals for passengers on the trains. (Glacier House and Mount Stephen house later became centres for mountain climbing and sightseeing. Fraser Canyon House at North Bend also offered expanded accommodation facilities.)

The first railway surveys in western Canada had to satisfy many objectives. The surveyors first looked to discover all available routes. To choose the best route, they considered several factors relating to building and running the railway, including:

costs of construction

track gradients and curves

need for cuts and fills, bridging and tunneling

snowfall and avalanche hazards

operating costs

Some routes had no easy option, leaving only long or steep grades which early locomotives struggled to climb. These grades were also dangerous when trains were descending.

For freight traffic, the railway could add locomotives or have shorter trains, although this approach increased the railway’s overall operating costs.

For passenger traffic, the railway chose to replace dining cars with a series of dining stops in the mountains. The railway hired architect Thomas Charles Sorby to design buildings for three locations: Glacier House at Glacier, Mount Stephen House at Field, and Fraser Canyon House at North Bend. At first the buildings were rather simple, although they were later enlarged and converted into hotels.

Mount Stephen House opened in the fall of 1886.

Glacier House and Fraser Canyon House both opened in the summer of 1887.

This was the dining room at Fraser Canyon House in the 1890s.

In addition to Jean’s time at the mountain hotels in British Columbia, she was also a manager from 1895 to 1911 at Lake Louise (which was sometimes called “Laggan”).

This was Lake Louise Chalet in the early 1900s.

While Jean was in North Bend, she occasionally travelled to Vancouver, where she would take part in local social events. Sometimes she would perform with local musicians and entertainers. Her specialty was well-known Scottish songs. One of her earliest performances was in 1890.

Changes in the Early 1900s

In 1904, Jean and her sister, Annie, bought the former residence of Anglican Bishop Cyprian Pinkham, which was at 215 Fourth Avenue S.W. in Calgary. They began to run it as a hotel and boarding house called Braemar Lodge.

Jean’s father, James Mollison, died in Calgary on October 12, 1905.

Around this time, Jean was still associated with the hotels in North Bend and Lake Louise.

In 1906, Annie and Jean renovated and enlarged Braemar Lodge in Calgary. The architects were Francis James Lawson (1860-1952) and James Joseph O’Gara (1876-1931). As security to finance the project, they used the Willow Creek property near Fort MacLeod, which they had inherited from their father.

The postcard below shows the results of the additions and alterations.

Annie and Jean operated Braemar Lodge together until December 1914, when Jean sold her interest to Annie. (Annie continued to operate Braemar Lodge until she died in 1929.)

By 1907, Jean began to have trouble with her eyesight, and she felt that she could no longer manage Fraser Canyon House at North Bend. It was not until several years later that she had surgery to correct her vision.

Jean Takes over Glencoe Lodge

At the end of September 1907, the Vancouver Province noted that “Miss Mollison,” the manageress of the Lake Louse Chalet, was staying at the Hotel Vancouver.

On September 30, the Province reported that Jean had leased the Rogers Hotel at the corner of Burrard Street and Georgia Street.

At this time the hotel was new, and it was only about half as large as it would become later. (Further information appears on the page for Glencoe Lodge.)

The early news references said that the hotel was to be called the “Gleneve.”

Soon the hotel had a new name: Glencoe Lodge. It quickly became a successful and well-known destination for both tourists and long-term residents. As well, prominent society members regularly held meetings and parties at the Lodge.

In 1908 and 1909, Jean went back to manage the Lake Louise Chalet for the summer. While Jean was away, Mildred Hawes looked after Glencoe Lodge.

In 1909, renovations doubled the original size of Glencoe Lodge. Jean continued to lease the Lodge until the early 1930s.

For some years, Jean arranged for another person to look after Glencoe Lodge during the summer. In 1910 and 1911, Jessie Dewar was the manager

Glenshiel Inn

From 1912 to about 1925, Jean was the proprietor of the Glenshiel Inn in Victoria.

L.E. Gooding had built the hotel in 1909, and he called it The Criterion.

Louis Ebenezer Gooding was a mining engineer who was born in Lockport, Illinois about 1870.

In 1901 he was living in the Kootenay region of British Columbia. By 1909, he was working as an assayer in Crofton, British Columbia.

He later lived in the United States. In 1934, he was in Berkeley, California.

He died in 1938.

Jean bought the Criterion Hotel in December 1911. She planned to enlarge the building to accommodate more guests.

This excerpt from a 1911 fire insurance plan shows the Glenshiel Inn before the additions.

After Jean acquired the hotel, Fred Cancellor became the manager from 1912 to 1915. (Fred was a brother of Herbert Cancellor, who was married to Jean’s sister, Jessie.)

In 1915, Jean’s sister, Hellen Patterson, took over the management of the Glenshiel Inn.

From 1919 to 1925, Harriett Jane Wood (1869-1946) was the manager.

By 1925, Violet Mary Allen had taken over the Glenshiel Inn. She arranged to enlarge the building.

Violet Allen died in Plymouth, England in 1933.

The Glenshiel continued as a hotel until 1972.

In 1958, the hotel added the “Thistle Room,” which was a dining room with view windows.

In 1972, the Province of British Columbia acquired the property. The building is currently a residence for senior citizens.

Strathcona Lodge

In 1912, Jean became the proprietor of the Strathcona Hotel, which was on the shore of Shawnigan Lake on Vancouver Island. The hotel was next to a railway line, which made it a convenient stop for tourists and vacationers.

The hotel was about twelve years old, and it was actually the second building on the site. The first version of the hotel was almost finished when a fire destroyed it, and the builders had to start over.

The reconstruction of the hotel began in June 1900.

The hotel opened on September 19, 1900

In 1903, Mrs. Josephine Elizabeth Wark (1866-1942) bought the hotel.

In 1911, Mrs. Wark attempted to sell the hotel to Louis Lucas and John P. Sweeney.

The Lucas and Sweeney transaction fell through, and in early 1912, Jean Mollison became the owner of the hotel.

The hotel was temporarily closed for renovations.

When the hotel re-opened in June 1912, its new name was Strathcona Lodge.

In September 1912, Jean organized a company called Mollison Sisters Limited to take over the ownership of Strathcona Lodge.

Jean and her sisters, Hellen and Jessie, initially each took one share in the company.

By February 1913, Jean’s brother-in-law, Herbert Cancellor, was Strathcona Lodge’s manager.

Although Strathcona Lodge remained in business for about another 13 years, Jean was no longer advertising the Lodge after the fall of 1914. By 1916, she had sold it to the Canadian Pacific Railway. By about the same time she had also given up her lease for the Cameron Lake Chalet.

By the mid-1920s the Lodge’s business had decreased, partly because automobile travel on Vancouver Island tended to bypass Shawnigan Lake.

After the Lodge closed in August 1927, the building became Strathcona Lodge School, with Wilhelmina (“Minna”) Gildea (1875-1950) as the headmistress. After Minna died in 1950, the school was closed until it re-opened in 1959. It closed again in 1977.

Cameron Lake Chalet

In June 1912, Jean leased the Cameron Lake Chalet from the Canadian Pacific Railway. The chalet was a combination station and hotel that the Esquimalt and Nanaimo Railway had built at the east end of Cameron Lake.

Herbert Cancellor, Jean’s brother-in-law, was the manager of the Cameron Lake Chalet until he and his brother moved to the Brentwood Hotel at Saanichton Inlet.

By early 1915, Albert Morton Monks and his wife, May, were managing the chalet.

Albert was born in Ipswich, England on June 20, 1882. On August 3, 1912, at Port Moody, British Columbia, Albert married May Savatard.

On November 12, 1915, Albert signed his attestation papers to serve with the Canadian military forces during the First World War.

Albert was killed in action on August 21, 1917. His a war commemoration is at the Vimy Memorial.

For a time, George W. Woolett took charge of the chalet.

May Monks later returned as the manager.

By the mid-1930s, May had retired, and in 1935 she travelled to England.

She died in London, England on December 23, 1935.

A series of tenants later operated the property until the 1960s.

Glencoe Lodge: Later Years

Glencoe Lodge was quite prosperous for much of its history, even during the First World War. After Benjamin Tingley Rogers, the hotel owner, died in 1918, his wife inherited the property. Jean continued to lease the hotel, which did well until the end of the 1920s.

However, the arrival of the Great Depression brought an end to this success. Many tenants were unable to pay their rents, and Jean tried to re-negotiate her terms with Mrs. Rogers. By 1931, Mrs. Rogers ended Jean’s lease, and Glencoe Lodge became the short-lived Belfred Hotel.

By December 1931, Jean had established a much smaller Glencoe Lodge at 2020 Barclay Street, which was the former house of Frederick Buscombe.

During the first year of the New Glencoe Lodge, Jean also lived in the house at 2020 Barclay Street. By 1934 she had moved her residence to 1649 Davie Street, although she may have briefly kept the new Glencoe Lodge operating at Barclay Street.

The house at 1649 Davie Street was midway between Cardero Street and Bidwell Street, on the north side of the block. (The house had been a rental building for many years. Alfred McGowan Pease had lived in the house from 1908 to 1912.)

By May 1934, the New Glencoe Lodge was out of business, and new managers had taken over at 2020 Barclay Street.

In the summer of 1935, Jean opened the Glencoe Lodge Coffee Shop at 1213 Granville Street.

The coffee shop was on the ground floor of the Austin Hotel (formerly known as the Granville Palace Hotel). The shop space had previously been the location of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, followed by an auctioneer’s business and a government liquor store.

Jean had given a chattel mortgage to secure money that she had borrowed, possibly to keep the coffee shop open. In November 1936, the holder of the chattel mortgage auctioned much of Jean’s collection of furniture and antiques.

In 1937, a bailiff seized and sold the furniture and equipment from the coffee shop to pay the arrears of rent.

Jean continued to live at 1649 Davie Street until 1951. From 1945 to 1947, Mrs. Jessie Pace (1877-1959) also lived in part of the house.

In Jean’s later years, many Vancouver residents and visitors still had fond memories of Glencoe Lodge. In 1946, the Vancouver Province published an article about the Lodge, which also included some of Jean’s recollections about the Mollison family history.

Jean died at her home on Davie Street on March 23, 1951.

In June 1951, a bailiff sold Jean’s furniture and antiques to recover the rent that was owing to her landlord.

Other Children of James Mollison and Anne Bisset

Anne Elizabeth Mollison

Anne Elizabeth Mollison was born at Kinchyle, Inverness, Scotland on August 5, 1854. (She was often called “Annie.”)

In 1861, she was living with her parents in Wick, Caithness, Scotland. In 1871, she was with her parents in Dochgarroch, Invernessshire. In 1881, she was with her father in Dochgarroch.

From the late 1880s to the early 1900s, Annie and her sister, Jean, were managers at several Canadian Pacific Railway hotels, including Banff, Field, Lake Louise, Glacier House, and North Bend. In 1889, one of the Mollison sisters appeared in a society note in the Calgary Herald.

In 1904, Annie and Jean bought the former residence of Anglican Bishop Cyprian Pinkham at 215 Fourth Avenue S.W. in Calgary. They began to run it as a private hotel that they called Braemar Lodge.

Soon Annie and Jean acquired an annex to allow more guests to stay at the Lodge.

In 1906, Annie and Jean renovated and enlarged the Lodge. The cost was about $30,000.

Annie and Jean operated Braemar Lodge together until December 1914, when Jean sold her interest to Annie.

Annie continued to operate Braemar Lodge until she died in 1929.

Braemar Lodge: Later Years

After Annie Mollison died, Braemar Lodge continued to operate under a series of managers until the 1960s.

In 1964, Calgary Motor Products Limited bought the property to use as a parking lot.

In February 1965, while the former Lodge was being demolished, a fire started on the main floor of the east wing. The fire spread until it destroyed almost all of the building.

Calgary Motor Products continued to use the property until the 1970s.

In the mid-1970s, a company called Rank City Wall planned to build a hotel on the former Braemar site. However, by 1975, the hotel project had become uneconomical, and the developers announced that they were building a group of office towers instead.

In 1976, Rank City Wall sold their interest to Olympia and York, a Toronto-based development company.

In 1978, Olympia and York was planning to go ahead with an office tower project.

By the fall of 1979, contractors were building the first part of the project, which was called “Esso Plaza.” (See: “Esso Plaza,” Calgary Architecture: The Boom Years 1972-1982, by Pierre S. Guimond and Brian R. Sinclair; Calgary, Detselig Enterprises Ltd., 1984, pages 38-39.)

Esso Plaza officially opened on June 29, 1981.

After Olympia and York’s financial failures in the 1990s, the office complex became known as “Fifth Avenue Place.”

James William Mollison

James William Mollison was born in Dores, Inverness, Scotland on July 9, 1857.

In 1861, he was living with his parents in Wick, Caithness, Scotland. In 1871, he was with his parents in Dochgarroch, Invernessshire, Scotland.

In 1877, he won prizes for achievement at the Cirencester Agricultural College.

In 1881, he was a farm manager in Collingbourne-Kingston, Wiltshire, England.

In 1885, James Mollison, Junior of Pavenham, Bedfordshire won prizes for poultry at the agricultural show at Preston. (He had already been in Canada by this time, so he may have returned to England, or perhaps someone entered the poultry under his name.)

In the 1880s, he was a manager of the Waldron Ranch Company in what is now southern Alberta.

On October 16, 1890, in the parish of St. Paul, Deptford, in London, England, James married Katherine Hardy. She was born on June 6, 1866, in Whittlesey, Cambridgeshire. Her parents were Henry Hardy (1834–1881) and Mary Cattle (born about 1836). The wedding register described James as a “professor of agriculture.”

About 1890, James and Katherine went to India, where James began a career as a scientific agriculturalist. On November 24, 1890, he became the superintendent of farms in Bombay. In October 1901, he received an appointment as Inspector-General of Agriculture for the Government of India.

While James and Katherine were in India, they had a son, Robert Wallace Mollison, who was born in Poona (now Pune), India on April 14, 1892.

Katherine died on the island of Guernsey on January 24, 1897.

James published works on agriculture in India, including Cultivation of the Betel-Palm, Cardamom and Pepper in the Kanara District of the Bombay Presidency (1900); and A Text-Book of Indian Agriculture (1901).

On September 18, 1901, in Holborn, Camden, England, James married Edith Mary McRae. She was born in Beddington, Surrey about 1859. Her parents were James McRae and Georgina Jane Roberts.

In 1911, James and Edith were living at a house called Ascotts in Felbridge, East Grinstead, Sussex. The 1911 England census described James as the Inspector General of Agriculture, Indian Service, on leave.

James became a Companion in the Order of the Star of India in 1911.

He retired in 1912.

He died on October 4, 1927.

The obituary notice in The Times of London stated that James was born in Canada, rather than in Scotland. (The Canadian newspapers that carried a version of the obituary also said that he was born in Canada.)

In 1939, Edith Mollison was living in Esher, Surrey, England.

Edith died on July 8, 1948.

Robert Wallace Mollison (son of James William Mollison)

James William Mollison and Katherine Hardy had a son named Robert Wallace Mollison, who was born in Poona (now Pune), India on April 14, 1892.

In March 1897, he travelled with his aunt, Martha Hardy, from Southampton, England to New York City. Their travel document indicated that they were on a “protracted sojourn.” (Robert’s mother, Katherine, had died on January 27, 1897.)

Martha Hardy later lived at Glencoe Lodge in Vancouver. She died in Vancouver on March 3, 1920.

During his early working life, Robert worked as a journalist.

On January 20, 1915, in Toronto, Ontario, he signed his attestation paper to join the Canadian Expeditionary Force during the First World War. His next of kin was his father, James Mollison, whose address was near East Grinstead in Surrey, England.

On December 20, 1915, the Canadian military forces discharged Robert, which allowed him to obtain a commission in the British R.F.A. (Royal Field Artillery).

After the war, Robert lived with his father at Ascotts, near East Grinstead.

In 1920, he travelled to Vancouver to visit his aunt, Jean, at Glencoe Lodge.

At the time of the 1921 Canada census, Robert was living on Highview Crescent in Toronto, Ontario. He was working as a manager of an electrical appliance business.

The 1922 Toronto directory described him as a salesman with Blue Bird Sales Limited, a Toronto-based firm that sold electrical appliances.

About 1922, Robert immigrated to the United States, where he worked as a sales manager.

On August 26, 1925, in Wellington Villa, Virginia, he married Katherine Peabody Rice. She was born in Ottumway, Iowa on June 6, 1896. Her parents were George Samuel Rice and Julia Maria Sessions.

In 1935, Katherine inherited a portion of a large estate from her wealthy uncle, Nelson Stanley Spencer.

Katherine was a talented painter who used “Kay Mollison” as her professional name.

For some time, Robert and Katherine lived at 37 Glen Road in Wellesley, Massachusetts.

In 1940, Robert applied to become a naturalized United States citizen.

He became a naturalized citizen on November 18, 1940.

Robert’s and Katherine’s marriage ended in divorce. On March 12, 1954, in Nashua, New Hampshire, Robert married Katherine Elizabeth Stephenson. She was born on May 28, 1919 in Albany, New York. Her parents were Kennard Frierson Stephenson (1888-1942) and Mary Dodd Flugel (1895-1980).

Katherine’s mother died in 1980.

Robert died on May 26, 1970.

Katherine died on October 25, 1991 in Chatham, Massachusetts.

Katherine Mollison (née Rice): Later Years

Robert Mollison’s first wife, Katherine, married Harry Russell Ballinger. Harry was a commercial artist, teacher, and author, who was known for his paintings of seascapes and boating scenes. He had earlier been married to Madeleine Grace Waters (1897-1964).

Katherine died in Torrington, Connecticut on June 8, 1980.

Harry Ballinger died in 1993.

Robert Wallace Mollison and Katherine Rice had two children: Oliver Spencer Mollison and Jean Katherine Mollison.

Oliver Spencer Mollison

Oliver Spencer Mollison was born in Moorestown, New Jersey on July 23, 1926.

He served as a commissioned officer in the United States Navy.

In 1949 he married Barbara Polsey.

Oliver was living in San Mateo, California in the early 1990s. He died on April 18, 1992.

Jean Katherine Mollison

Jean Katherine Mollison was in Moorestown, New Jersey on July 30, 1927.

She studied at Smith College.

On April 4, 1959, in Arlington, Virginia, she married Luther Russel Gobbel, who was a lawyer with the United States Navy. He was born in Durham, North Carolina on May 17, 1930. His parents were Luther Lafayette Gobbel and Marcia Rachel Russell.

Luther died in Columbia, Maryland on May 31, 2014.

Jean died on January 19, 2015.

Hellen Mary Mollison

Hellen Mary Mollison was born at Wick, Caithness, Scotland on September 27, 1859. (She normally spelled her first name with two “l”s. Her father had an older sister who also spelled her name as “Hellen.”)

In 1861, Hellen was living with her parents in Wick. In 1871, she was with her parents in Dochgarroch, Invernessshire.

By 1881, she was living with her brother, James, in Collingbourne-Kingston, Wiltshire, England

A person named Helen M. Mollison arrived in Canada on July 23, 1889.

On February 20, 1894, Hellen married Thomas Foreman Patterson in Calgary, Northwest Territories.

Thomas was born on July 10, 1864. (His birthplace was either in England or Quebec; the sources are not consistent.) His parents were Andrew Jeffrey Patterson and Elizabeth Foreman.

At the time of the 1901 Canada census, Thomas, Hellen and their son, Jack, were living in Nelson, British Columbia. Thomas was a locomotive foreman.

In 1905, they were in Kenora, Ontario, where Thomas was a locomotive foreman.

In 1911, they lived in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. Thomas was a master mechanic with the Canadian Pacific Railway.

In 1921, they were at Glacier, British Columbia. Thomas was a tunnel ventilation engineer.

By 1927, Thomas and Hellen had moved to 529 Harbinger Avenue in Victoria, British Columbia. Thomas was retired.

Thomas died in Victoria on June 27, 1940. He was buried in Lake Of The Woods Cemetery in Kenora, Ontario.

Helen died in Vancouver on March 21, 1944. She was buried in Lake Of The Woods Cemetery in Kenora.

Thomas and Hellen had a son, John (“Jack”) Foreman Patterson, who was born in Winnipeg, Manitoba, on November 17, 1897.

In 1905, the Pattersons were living in Kenora, Ontario. On August 11, 1905, Jack drowned after he fell from a bridge.

He was buried in Lake Of The Woods Cemetery in Kenora.

Jessie Mollison

Jessie Mollison was born on June 4, 1863 at Kingussie and Insch, Inverness-shire, Scotland.

In 1871, she was living at Dochgarroch with her parents.

In 1881, she was a student in London, England.

On June 3, 1897, at North Bend, British Columbia, she married Herbert Cancellor, who was a provincial constable based at North Bend. He was born in London, England on July 9, 1864. His parents were Francis Cancellor and Frances Emily Webb.

Herbert was a caterer and manager of several hotels in British Columbia.

In 1899, he was with the Pine Tree Hotel, at Discovery, near Atlin.

In 1905, Herbert became a justice of the peace in Atlin.

The 1911 Canada census described Herbert as a farmer, living at Chemainus, North Cowichan.

For a time, Herbert was associated with Cameron Lake Chalet, which was a combination station and hotel that the Esquimalt and Nanaimo Railway built at the east end of Cameron Lake.

In 1915, Herbert and his brother, Fred, took over the Brentwood Hotel at Saanichton Inlet.

By 1920, Herbert was a farmer in Summerland, British Columbia.

In 1924, Herbert and Jessie moved to Chemainus on Vancouver Island.

Jessie died in Vancouver on December 10, 1929. She was buried in Ocean View Burial Park in Burnaby, British Columbia.

Herbert died in Victoria, British Columbia on May 29, 1942. He was buried in Ross Bay Cemetery in Victoria.

Andrew Oliver Mollison

Andrew Oliver Mollison was born on March 17, 1865 at Elgin, Morayshire, Scotland

In 1871, he was living with his parents at Dochgarroch, Scotland. In 1881, he was with his father at Dochgarroch.

While Andrew was in Scotland, he had become ill with tuberculosis. Some medical advisors in those days thought that a climate of sunshine, dry air, and high altitude might improve the health of tuberculosis patients. Parts of western Canada had this type of climate, so that may have been one of the reasons that the Mollisons moved to Canada.

In 1891, Andrew was with his father at Willow Creek near Fort MacLeod in the Northwest Territories.

The climate in Canada did not stop the tuberculosis. Andrew died on September 17, 1891, and he was buried in the Union Cemetery at Fort MacLeod.

Frederick William Alpin Gordon Haultain (1857-1942), a lawyer and politician who was then living in Fort Macleod, became the interim receiver to look after Andrew’s estate.

Robert Bisset Mollison

Robert Bisset Mollison was born on February 7, 1869 at Tain, Ross and Cromarty, Scotland.

In 1871, he was living with his parents at Dochgarroch, Scotland. In 1881, he was with his father at Dochgarroch.

In 1891, he was with his father at Willow Creek near Fort MacLeod in the Northwest Territories.

He suffered from diabetes. He received treatment from Robert George Brett, MD (1851-1929), a well-known doctor in Banff, and from George Allan Kennedy, MB (1858-1913), who had a medical practice in Fort MacLeod

In 1892, Robert sent samples of his grain to Wesley Fletcher Orr, who was a Calgary city councillor (and later Calgary’s mayor). The local Canadian Pacific Railway officials displayed the grain in their land office.

In January 1893, the sheriff seized and sold Robert’s assets to pay outstanding debts.

He died at Field, British Columbia on August 7, 1893. Rev. Ronald Hilton presided at the ceremony when Robert was buried in the Union Cemetery at Fort MacLeod.

Sir John Lister-Kaye, 3rd Baronet; Wikipedia article; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_John_Lister-Kaye,_3rd_Baronet.

Some Memories of the Old “76,” by Mrs. S.E. Warren, Canadian Cattlemen, September 1949, page 20; http://static.canadiancattlemen.ca/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Some-memories-of-the-old-76-Sept.49.pdf.

Canadian Agricultural, Coal and Colonization Company; https://albertaonrecord.ca/canadian-agricultural-coal-and-colonization-company-2: “The Canadian Agricultural, Coal and Colonization Company was started in 1887 by Sir John Lister-Kaye, a member of the British nobility who came to Balgonie, Saskatchewan in 1885. The company acquired eleven large tracts of land (about 10,000 acres or 4000 hectares apiece) from Balgonie, Saskatchewan to Namaka, Alberta, on which it was intended to use the latest methods of cultivation and breeding. In 1888 the company purchased the cattle of the Powder River Cattle Company and entered the ranching business. In 1889 D.H. Andrews was appointed manager of the stock operations. The Stair Ranch, near Redcliff, Alberta, was one of the tracts of land kept primarily as a ranching operation. Andrews started the Canada Land and Ranch Company in 1895 and took over CACCC’s operations.”

Canadian Agricultural, Coal, and Colonization Company, Sunday Times (London, England), June 8, 1890, page 2, column 5.

History of Saskatchewan and The Old North West; Chapter XLIII – Colonization Companies and Analogous Enterprises: Anglo-Saxon Immigration; https://www.electriccanadian.com/history/saskatchewan/sask/chapter43.htm:

“A similar history has to be recorded in regard to the John Lister Kaye farms. Sir John’s first investment consisted of some six sections of lands near Balgonie, which he commenced to farm in 18S5. Associated with him in this venture were Lord Queensbury and others. In 1888 there was formed the Canadian Agricultural, Coal and Colonization Company, Limited. This concern took over the Balgonie farm and established nine others. These various farms averaged thirty-six square miles each in area.

Unfortunately the immediately available capital was invested with injudicious haste in buildings, stock and implements, and the management of the farms in many ways soon manifested deplorable ignorance of prairie conditions. The policy of the company was directed by a board in England, the majority of whom had never seen this country. As a colonization enterprise the whole scheme proved the same failure that it was as an investment. In a few years, however, some of the farms were sold and the control of the others passed to a new organization, the last of these being the Canada Land and Ranch Co., which under the management of practical business men proved profitable.”

There was a strong Scottish connection and many of the original managers were retired army captains associated with the Scottish Regiments”

“Yesterday and today: The Glenshiel embraces its second century,” Victoria News, April 1, 2019; https://www.vicnews.com/marketplace/yesterday-and-today-the-glenshiel-embraces-its-second-century/: “A Mr. L.E. Gooding named his new 20-room hotel The Criterion in 1908, a time when a city construction boom also saw the Empress Hotel and a final addition to St. Joseph’s Hospital built. In 1912, new owners of the hotel renamed it after the Glenshiel Estate owned by the Earls of Seaforth in the Scottish Highlands.”
